preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: Most mail servers in use on the Internet today lack any kind of interactive user interface. They receive mail, forward mail, and deliver mail without directly displaying any information as they do so. Although mail servers typically write log files recording the actions they take, using these files to debug problems or to monitor the SMTP transactions as they occur is difficult.

MailFlux is a specialized mail server that addresses these limitations. It provides an interactive console that the administrator can use to observe the behavior of the server in real time as well as to dynamically reconfigure the server. MailFlux is primarily an educational server, however it could also be used as a personal SMTP server or for debugging SMTP problems. In that respect MailFlux has the potential for real application outside the classroom.

This document describes how to use MailFlux, with special emphasis on the program's unique features. The internal design of MailFlux is described in an accompanying Developer's Guide. If you are a mail administrator interested in using MailFlux to debug SMTP problems, or if you are a student interested in learning about the SMTP protocol, then you should read just this User's Guide. If you are a developer interested extending or enhancing MailFlux, then you should read both the User's Guide and the Developer's Guide. All MailFlux users may be especially interested in reviewing the Future Directions section of this guide to get an idea of what to expect in later versions of the program.
